Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Functional diversity of chemosymbiosis in lucinid bivalves from coastal biomes
Award.AbstractNarration:
All known clams of the Lucinidae family harbor chemosymbiotic bacteria that fix carbon and supply it to their hosts in the absence of sunlight. Because lucinids are very abundant in shallow marine sediments, their effects on porewater composition, nutrient suspension, sediment biogeochemistry and vegetation productivity are considerable. However, their roles in sediment N and methane cycling are unknown, especially compared to other chemosymbiotic systems in deep-marine settings. Moreover, it is unclear how a decline in lucinid populations and/or functional diversity may impact coastal biome and ecosystem services, or even what could lead to lucinid population declines overall. This project will investigate the underexplored genetic, taxonomic, and functional diversity of lucinid chemosymbioses in shallow marine environments ranging from pristine to highly altered. Sampling will take place in Florida, California, and The Bahamas. The investigators will also test for ways to characterize lucinid-bacteria biodiversity in the geologic past. This research is expected to fill gaps in our understanding of lucinid chemosymbiotic systems, including how gene expression is altered for lucinids and their endosymbionts in changing ecosystem conditions, particularly due to anthropogenic impact.

This research will fill a major gap in understanding lucinid biodiversity loss that may occur in habitats sensitive to natural and anthropogenic disturbances and will be important for coastal resource management decisions. The researchers will provide interdisciplinary training in geochemistry, microbiology, and paleobiology to graduate and undergraduate students, including field studies in The Bahamas, training in museum collection standards, laboratory research, and computational bioinformatics. Students from underrepresented STEM groups will be involved on the project, and involvement with university outreach and mentoring programs will target symbiosis and biodiversity topics through formal and informal classroom, public speaking opportunities, and museum activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Dimensions of Diversity project sought to uncover the genetic, taxonomic, and functional diversity of lucinid bivalves and their bacterial symbionts from coastal marine habitats that range from pristine to highly altered conditions. Lucinids are common in coastal marine sediments, including within seagrass meadows and mangrove forests, and are the most diverse group of bivalves to house, within their gills, microbes that use sulfur compounds for biosynthesis. The project was a collaboration among three PIs at three institutions: Annette Engel at the University of Tennessee Knoxville (#1342785), Barbara Campbell at Clemson University (#1342763) and Laurie Anderson at the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSM&T) (#1342721). Because the three projects have different end dates, this outcomes report focuses on activities at SDSM&T.

Anderson’s portion of the project focused on the hypothesis that taxonomic, genetic, and functional aspects of symbiont biodiversity influence the morphology of their bivalve hosts in ways that are preserved on lucinid shells and, therefore, are potentially detectable in the fossil record. Quantitative techniques were used to examine how morphology varies within populations and among species. In addition, genetic sequence data and discrete morphologic characters were developed and used to examine patterns of evolutionary relationships among fossil and modern lucinid species.

This research demonstrated that morphology is strongly associated with body size and this association persists across species and genera. Nonetheless, morphology can be used within species to track environmental conditions, such as the stability of seagrass cover or the type of sediment lucinids inhabit.  These same techniques were used to document pervasive differences between live and dead specimens across species and habitats. Finally, a combination of molecular and morphologic data detected cryptic diversity in lucinids inhabiting inland lakes with marine salinities.

Mentoring, training, and outreach activities were integral to this project. Two graduate students, two undergraduate students, and one research scientist received training as part of this grant. Two MS thesis and an in-progress PhD dissertation resulted from this research. In addition, a field course in Coastal Biomes was taught, a physical exhibit for the SDSM&T Museum of Geology was developed, as was a virtual exhibit on Symbiosis through Time (https://prezi.com/qfmvaz6zksu0/symbiosis-through-time/?utm_campaign=share&utm_medium=copy). As a Dimension of Biodiveristy project, specimens and ancillary data collected are curated, cataloged and digitized into the SDSM&T Museum of Geology collections database. To date 2,265 lots representing 11,042 specimens have been digitally cataloged. These records are made publicly available online through the iDigBio portal (https://www.idigbio.org/portal/recordsets/db3181c9-48dd-489f-96ab-a5888f5a938c) as well as the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (https://www.gbif.org/publisher/f3b58cd2-a559-4f3a-b94d-01448b508821)
